name: Planetary Equilibrium Temperature
explanation: Equilibrium temperature is temperature planet reaches when incoming solar radiation equals outgoing thermal radiation. Depends on stellar luminosity (L), distance (d), and albedo (A - reflectivity). Used to determine habitable zones and understand planetary climates. Planets closer to star or with lower albedo are hotter.

examples.problem: Why is Venus so hot despite being farther from Sun than Mercury?
examples.solution: Venus has very low albedo and thick atmosphere (greenhouse effect)
steps: But thick CO₂ atmosphere traps heat
Greenhouse effect raises temperature far above equilibrium

examples.solution: Distance range where equilibrium temperature allows liquid water
steps: Too close: too hot, water boils
Too far: too cold, water freezes
Habitable zone: ~0.7-1.5 AU for Sun-like star
Also depends on atmosphere and greenhouse effect
